title: 111_hr2324
content: The Act titled "Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2009" aims to implement background checks at gun shows. The Congress finds that approximately 5,200 gun shows are held annually in the US, attracting many attendees and sellers. These shows provide easy access for criminals and prohibited persons to obtain firearms without background checks or traceable records. The Firearms Owners' Protection Act exempts certain offers or exhibits of firearms from regulation if they involve personal collections or events with limited firearm numbers organized by hunting-focused non-profit organizations. The Firearms Owners' Protection Act exempts gun show vendors who are not licensed under section 923 and only attend events with permanent or annual dues-paying members and their immediate families. This includes exhibiting, selling, offering for sale, transferring, or exchanging firearms at gun shows. Additionally, the Act regulates firearms transfers at gun shows by requiring registration of gun show operators. Gun show operators must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited from transporting firearms, have not violated any laws, and must register with the Attorney General. Gun show operators must register with the Attorney General by providing a photograph, fingerprints, certification of meeting requirements, disclosing all material information, making no false statements, and paying a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. Gun show operators must notify the Attorney General 30 days before the show with details of vendors and verify their identities with valid identification documents containing a photograph. Gun show operators must have individuals sign a ledger with identifying information and a notice of obligations, and notify attendees of the requirements. Records must be maintained to demonstrate compliance. Gun show operators must have individuals sign a ledger with identifying information and a notice of obligations, and notify attendees of the requirements. Records must be maintained to demonstrate compliance with regulations set by the Attorney General for the transfer of firearms between unlicensed persons at gun shows. The licensee must provide required information for a firearm transfer, notify parties about the background check system, and submit a transfer report to the Attorney General within 10 days. The licensee must submit a transfer report to the Attorney General with details of the firearm, as required by regulations. The report should not include personal information of unlicensed individuals involved in the transfer. Additionally, the licensee must keep a record of the transfer in their permanent business records. The Attorney General is prohibited from imposing recordkeeping requirements on gun show vendors under this section. The penalties for violating subsections of section 932 include fines and imprisonment for up to 5 years. The Attorney General may impose additional penalties on those who knowingly violate any provision of section 932. The Attorney General may suspend or revoke the registration of a person under section 932(a) and impose a civil fine of up to $10,000 after a hearing. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents for chapter 44 of the title. The Attorney General has the authority to inspect gun show operators' records and inventory to ensure compliance with firearm regulations. Increased penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensees at gun shows, including fines for false statements or violations of required information. Increased penalties for violations of criminal background check requirements under section 922 of the title, including fines and imprisonment for various offenses. Penalties range from 1 year to 10 years depending on the specific violation. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives may hire additional personnel to inspect gun shows and must report biennially to Congress on firearm sales at these shows. (j) This section requires reporting on firearm sales at gun shows to ensure background checks are conducted by the national instant criminal background check system. It also includes provisions for necessary resources and recommendations for improvements. Effective date is 180 days after enactment.
